div1.p: A TRIP TO SCARBOROUGH A COMEDY.
A TRIP TO SCARBOROUGH. A COMEDY. AS PERFORMED AT THE THEATRE ROYAL IN DRURY LANE.
ALTERED FROM Vanbrugh's Relapse; or, Virtue in Danger.
LONDON. Printed for G. WILKIE, No. 71, St. Paul's Church-yard. MDCCLXXXI.

lg.l: WHAT various transformations we remark,
From East Whitechapel to the West Hyde-park!
Men, women, children, houses, signs, and fashions,
State, stage, trade, taste, the humours and the passions;
Th' Exchange, 'Change alley, wheresoe'er your ranging,
Court, city, country, all are chang'd, or changing;
The streets sometime ago, were pav'd with stones,
Which, aided by a hackney coach, half broke your bones.
The purest lovers then indulg'd no bliss;
They run great hazard if they stole a kiss—

l.hi: One chaste salute—the Damsel cry'd, O fye!

lg.l: As they approach'd, slap went the coach awry,
—Poor Sylvia got a bump, and Damon a black eye.
But now weak nerves in hackney coaches roam,
And the cramm'd glutton snores unjolted home:
Of former times that polish'd thing a Beau,
Is metamorphos'd now, from top to toe;
Then the full flaxen wig, spread o'er the shoulders,
Conceal'd the shallow head from the beholders!
But now the whole's revers'd—each fop appears,
Cropp'd, and trimm'd up—exposing head and ears;
The buckle then it's modest limits knew—
Now, like the ocean, dreadful to the view,
Hath broke it's bounds, and swallows up the shoe;
The wearer's foot, like his once fine estate,
Is almost lost, th' incumbrance is so great.
Ladies may smile—are they not in the plot?
The bounds of nature have not they forgot?
Were they design'd to be, when put together,
Made up, like shuttlecocks, of cork and feather?
Their pale fac'd grand-mama's appear'd with grace,
When dawning blushes rose upon the face;
No blushes now their once lov'd station seek,
The foe is in possession of the cheek!
No head of old, too high in feather'd state,
Hinder'd the fair to pass the lowest gate;
A church to enter now, they must be bent,
If ev'n they should try th' experiment.
As change thus circulates throughout the nation,
Some plays may justly call for alteration;
At least to draw some slender cov'ring o'er
That graceless wit,And Van wants Grace, who never wanted Wit. POPE. which was too bare before:
Those writers well and wisely use their pens,
Who turn our Wantons into Magdalens;
And howsoever wicked wits revile 'em,
We hope to find in you, their Stage Asylum.

body.head: A TRIP TO SCARBOROUGH, A COMEDY.

div2.head: SCENE I. the Hall of an Inn.
div2.stage: Enter YOUNG FASHION and LORY—Postillion following with a Portmanteau.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: LORY, pay the post-boy, and take the portmanteau.

sp.speaker: LORY.
sp.p: Faith, sir, we had better let the post-boy take the portmanteau and pay himself.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Why sure there's something lest in it.

sp.speaker: LORY.
sp.p:
Not a rag, upon my honour, sir—we eat the
last of your wardrobe at Newmalton—and if we had had twenty miles farther to go, our next meal must have been off the cloak-bag.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Why 'sdeath it appears full.

sp.speaker: LORY.
sp.p: Yes, sir—I made bold to stuff it with hay, to save appearances, and look like baggage.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: What the devil shall I do!—harkee, boy, what's the chaise?

sp.speaker: BOY.
sp.p: Thirteen shillings, please your honour.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Can you give me change for a guinea?

sp.speaker: BOY.
sp.p: O yes, sir.

sp.speaker: LORY.
sp.p: Soh, what will he do now?—Lord, sir, you had better let the boy be paid below.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Why, as you say, Lory, I believe it will be as well.

sp.speaker: LORY.
sp.p: Yes, yes; tell them to discharge you below, honest friend.

sp.speaker: BOY.
sp.p: Please your honour, there are the turnpikes too.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Aye, aye; the turnpikes by all means.

sp.speaker: BOY.
sp.p: And I hope your honour will order me something for myself.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: To be sure, bid them give you a crown.

sp.speaker: LORY.
sp.p: Yes, yes—my master doesn't care what you charge them—so get along you—

sp.speaker: BOY.
sp.p: Your honour promised to send the hostler—

sp.speaker: LORY.
sp.p: P'shaw! damn the hostler—would you impose upon the gentleman's generosity?— (Pushes him out)—A rascal, to be so curst ready with his change!

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Why faith, Lory, he had near pos'd me.

sp.speaker: LORY.
sp.p: Well, sir, we are arrived at Scarborough, not worth a guinea!—I hope you'll own yourself a happy man—You have outliv'd all your cares.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: How so, sir?

sp.speaker: LORY.
sp.p: Why you have nothing left to take care of.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Yes, sirrah, I have myself and you to take care of still.

sp.speaker: LORY.
sp.p: Sir, if you could prevail with some-body else to do that for you, I fancy we might both fare the better for't—But now, sir, for my Lord Foppington, your elder brother.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Damn my eldest brother!

sp.speaker: LORY.
sp.p: With all my heart; but get him to redeem your annuity however.—Look you, sir, you must wheedle him, or you must starve.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Look you, sir, I will neither wheedle him nor starve.

sp.speaker: LORY.
sp.p: Why what will you do then?

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Cut his throat, or get some one to do it for me.

sp.speaker: LORY.
sp.p: Gad-so, sir, I'm glad to find I was not so we I acquainted with the strength of your conscience as with the weakness of your purse.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Why, art thou so impenetrable a blockhead as to believe he'll help me with a farthing?

sp.speaker: LORY.
sp.p: Not if you treat him de baut en bas as you used to do.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Why how would'st have me treat him?

sp.speaker: LORY.
sp.p: Like a trout—tickle him.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: I can't flatter.

sp.speaker: LORY.
sp.p: Can you starve?

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: LORY.
sp.p: I can't—Good-bye t'ye, sir.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Stay—thou'lt distract me. But who comes here—my old friend, Colonel Townly?
My dear Colonel, I am rejoiced to meet you here.

sp.speaker: TOWNLY.
sp.p: Dear Tom, this is an unexpected pleasure—what, are you come to Scarbro' to be present at your brother's wedding?

sp.speaker: LORY.
sp.p: Ah, sir, if it had been his funeral, we should have come with pleasure.

sp.speaker: TOWNLY.
sp.p: What, honest Lory, are you with your master still?

sp.speaker: LORY.
sp.p: Yes, sir, I have been starving with him ever since I saw your honour last.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Why, Lory is an attach'd rogue; there's no getting rid of him.

sp.speaker: LORY.
sp.p: True, sir, as my master says, there's no seducing me from his service, 'till he's able to pay me my wages. (Aside.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Go, go, sir—and take care of the baggage.

sp.speaker: LORY.
sp.p: Yes, sir—the baggage!—O Lord!—I suppose, sir, I must charge the landlord to be very particular where he stows this.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Get along, you rascal. [Exit Lory, with the Portmanteau.
But, Colonel, are you acquainted with my proposed sister-in-law?

sp.speaker: TOWNLY.
sp.p:
Only by character—her father, Sir Tunbelly Clumsey, lives within a quarter of a mile of this place, in a lonely old house, which nobody comes
near. She never goes abroad, nor sees company at home; to prevent all misfortunes, she has her breeding within doors; the parson of the parish teaches her to play upon the dulcimer; the clerk to sing, her nurse to dress, and her father to dance:—in short, nobody has free admission there but our old acquaintance, Mother Coupler, who has procured your brother this match, and is, I believe, a distant relation of Sir Tunbelly's.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: But is her fortune so considerable?

sp.speaker: TOWNLY.
sp.p: Three thousand a year, and a good sum of money independent of her father beside.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: 'Sdeath! that my old acquaintance, dame Coupler, could not have thought of me as well as my brother for such a prize.

sp.speaker: TOWNLY.
sp.p: Egad I wouldn't swear that you are too late—his Lordship, I know, hasn't yet seen the lady, and, I believe, has quarrelled with his patroness.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: My dear Colonel, what an idea have you started?

sp.speaker: TOWNLY.
sp.p: Pursue it if you can, and I promise you you shall have my assistance; for besides my natural contempt for his Lordship, I have at present the enmity of a rival towards him.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: What, has he been addressing your old flame, the sprightly widow Berinthia?

sp.speaker: TOWNLY.
sp.p: Faith, Tom, I am at present most whimsically circumstanced—I came here near a month ago to meet the lady you mention; but she failing in her promise, I, partly from pique, and partly from idleness, have been diverting my chagrin by offering up chaste incense to the beauties of Amanda, our friend Loveless's wife.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: I have never seen her, but have heard her spoken of as a youthful wonder of beauty and prudence.

sp.speaker: TOWNLY.
sp.p: She is so indeed; and Loveless being too careless and insensible of the treasure he possesses—my lodging in the same house has given me a thousand opportunities of making my assiduities acceptable; so that in less than a fortnight, I began to bear my disappointment from the widow, with the most Christian resignation.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: And Berinthia has never appear'd?

sp.speaker: TOWNLY.
sp.p: O there's the perplexity; for just as I began not to care whether I ever saw her again or not, last night she arrived.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: And instantly reassumed her empire.

sp.speaker: TOWNLY.
sp.p: No faith—we met—but the lady not condescending to giev me any serious reasons for having fool'd me for a month, I left her in a huff.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p:
Well, well, I'll answer for't, she'll soon resume her power, especially as friendship will prevent
your pursuing the other too far—but my coxcomb of a brother is an admirer of Amanda's too, is he?

sp.speaker: TOWNLY.
sp.p: Yes; and I believe is most heartily despised by her—but come with me, and you shall see her and your old friend Loveless.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: I must pay my respects to his Lordship—perhaps you can direct me to his lodgings.

sp.speaker: TOWNLY.
sp.p: Come with me, I shall pass by it.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: I wish you could pay the visit for me; or could tell me what I should say to him.

sp.speaker: TOWNLY.
sp.p: Say nothing to him—apply yourself to his bag, his sword, his feather, his snuff-box; and when you are well with them, desire him to lend you a thousand pounds, and I'll engage you prosper.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: 'Sdeath and furies! why was that coxcomb thrust into the world before me? O Fortune! Fortune! thou art a jilt, by Gad. [Exit

div2.head: SCENE II, a Dressing Room.
div2.stage: Lord FOPPINGTON, in his Night Gown, and LA VAROLE.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p:
Well, 'tis an unspeakable pleasure to be a man of quality—strike me dumb!—even the boors of
this Northern spa have learn'd the respect due to a title—La Varole!

sp.speaker: LA VAROLE.
sp.p: Mi Lor—

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: You han't yet been at Muddy-Moat-Hall to announce my arrival, have you?

sp.speaker: LA VAROLE.
sp.p: Not yet, mi Lor.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Then you need not go till Saturday, [Exit La Va. as I am in no particular haste to view my intended Sposa—I shall sacrifice a day or two more to the pursuit of my friend Loveless's wife—Amanda is a charming creature—strike me ugly; and if I have any discernment in the world, she thinks no less of my Lord Foppington.

sp.speaker: LA VAROLE.
sp.p: Mi Lor, de shoemaker, de taylor, de hosier, de sempstress, de peru, be all ready, if your lordship please to dress.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: 'Tis well, admit them.

sp.speaker: LA VAROLE.
sp.p: Hey, Messieurs, entrez.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: So, gentlemen, I hope you have all taken pains to shew yourselves masters in your professions.

sp.speaker: TAYLOR.
sp.p: I think I may presume to say, Sir—

sp.speaker: LA VAROLE.
sp.p: My Lor, you clown you!

sp.speaker: TAYLOR.
sp.p: My Lord, I ask your Lordship's pardon, my Lord. I hope, my Lord, your Lordship will please to own, I have brought your Lordship as accomplished a suit of clothes as ever Peer of England wore, my Lord—will your Lordship please to try 'em now?

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Ay; but let my people dispose the glasses so, that I may see myself before and behind; for I love to see myself all round.
sp.stage: (Whilst he puts on his clothes, enter YOUNG FASHION and LORY.)

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Hey-day! What the devil have we here?—Sure my gentleman's grown a favourite at court, he has got so many people at his levee.

sp.speaker: LORY.
sp.p: Sir, these people come in order to make him a favourite at court—they are to establish him with the ladies.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Good Heav'n! to what an ebb of taste are women fallen, that it should be in the power of a laced coat to recommend a gallant to them!

sp.speaker: LORY.
sp.p: Sir, Taylors and Hair-dressers are now become the bawds of the nation—'tis they that debauch all the women.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Thou say'st true; for there's that fop now has not, by nature, wherewithal to move a cook maid: and by the time these fellows have done with him, egad he shall melt down a Countess—but now for my reception.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Death and eternal tortures! Sir—I say the coat is too wide here by a foot.

sp.speaker: TAYLOR.
sp.p: My Lord, if it had been tighter, 'twould neither have hook'd nor button'd.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Rat the hooks and buttons, Sir, can any thing be worse than this?—As Gad shall jedge me! it hangs on my shoulders like a chairman's surtout.

sp.speaker: TAYLOR.
sp.p: 'Tis not for me to dispute your Lordship's fancy.

sp.speaker: LORY.
sp.p: There, Sir, observe what respect does.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Respect!—D—m him for a coxcomb—but let's accost him.—Brother, I'm your humble servant.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: O Lard, Tam, I did not expect you in England—Brother, I'm glad to see you—but what has brought you to Scarbro' Tam?—Look you, Sir, (to the Taylor) I shall never be reconciled to this nauseous wrapping gown; therefore, pray get me another suit with all possible expedition; for this is my eternal aversion—Well, but Tam, you don't tell me what has driven you to Scarbro'?—Mrs. Callicoe, are not you of my mind?

sp.speaker: SEMPSTRESS.
sp.p: Directly, my Lord.—I hope your Lordship is pleased with your ruffles?

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: In love with them, stab my vitals!—Bring my bill, you shall be paid to-morrow.

sp.speaker: SEMPSTRESS.
sp.p: I humbly thank your Lordship. [Exit Semp.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Heark thee, shoemaker, these shoes a'nt ugly, but they don't sit me.

sp.speaker: SHOEMAKER.
sp.p: My Lord, I think they fit you very well.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: They hurt me just below the instep.

sp.speaker: SHOEMAKER.
sp.p: (feeling his foot) No, my Lord, they don't hurt you there.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: I tell thee they pinch me execrably.

sp.speaker: SHOEMAKER.
sp.p: Why then, my Lord, if those shoes pinch you I'll be d—n'd.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Why wilt thou undertake to persuade me I cannot feel!

sp.speaker: SHOEMAKER.
sp.p: Your Lordship may please to feel what you think fit, but that shoe does not hurt you—I think I understand my trade.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Now by all that's good and powerful, thou art an incomprehensible coxcomb—but thou makest good shoes, and so I'll bear with thee.

sp.speaker: SHOEMAKER.
sp.p: My Lord, I have work'd for half the people of quality in this town these twenty years, and 'tis very hard I shoudn't know when a shoe hurts, and when it don't.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Well, prithee be gone about thy business. Exit Shoe.
Mr. Mendlegs, a word with you. The calves of these stockings are thicken'd a little too much; thy make my legs look like a porter's.

sp.speaker: MENDLEGS.
sp.p: My Lord, methinks they look mighty well.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Aye, but you are not so good a judge of those things as I am—I have study'd them all my life—therefore pray let the next be the thickness of a crown piece less.

sp.speaker: MENDLEGS.
sp.p: Indeed, my Lord, they are the same kind I had the honour to furnish your Lordship with in town.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Very possibly, Mr. Mendlegs; but that was in the beginning of the winter; and you should always remember, Mr. Hosier, that if you make a Nobleman's spring legs as robust as his autumnal calves, you commit a manstrous impropriety, and make no allowance for the fatigues of the winter.

sp.speaker: JEW.
sp.p: I hope, my Lord, those buckles have had the unspeakable satisfaction of being honoured with your Lordship's approbation?

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Why they are of a pretty fancy; but don't you think them rather of the smallest?

sp.speaker: JEW.
sp.p: My Lord, they could not well be larger to keep on your Lordship's shoe.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: My good Sir, you forget that these matters are not as they used to be: formerly, indeed, the buckle was a sort of machine, intended to keep on the shoe; but the case is now quite reversed, and the shoe is of no earthly use, but to keep on the buckle.—Now give me my watches, and the business of the morning will be pretty well over.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Well, Lory, what dost think on't?—a very friendly reception from a brother after three years absence!

sp.speaker: LORY.
sp.p: Why, Sir, 'tis your own fault—here you have stood ever since you came in, and have not commended any one thing that belongs to him.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Nor ever shall, while they belong to a coxcomb.—Now your people of business are gone, brother, I hope I may obtain a quarter of an hour's audience of you?

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Faith, Tam, I must beg you'll excuse me at this time, for I have an engagement which I would not break for the salvation of mankind. Hey!—there!—is my carriage at the door?—You'll excuse me, brother. [Going.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Shall you be back to dinner?

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: As Gad shall jedge me, I can't tell, for it is passible I may dine with some friends at Donner's.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Shall I meet you there? for I must needs talk with you.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: That I'm afraid may'nt be quite so praper;—for those I commonly eat with are a people of nice conversation; and you know, Tam, your education has been a little at large—but there are other ordinaries in town—very good beef ordinaries—I suppose, Tam, you can eat beef?—However, dear Tam, I'm glad to see thee in England, stap my vitals! [Exit.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Hell and furies! Is this to be borne?

sp.speaker: LORY.
sp.p: Faith, Sir, I could almost have given him a knock o' the pate myself.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: 'Tis enough; I will now shew you the excess of my passion, by being very calm.—Come, Lory, lay your loggerhead to mine, and, in cold blood, let us contrive his destruction.

sp.speaker: LORY.
sp.p: Here comes a head, Sir, would contrive it better than us both, if she would but join in the confederacy.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: By this light, Madam Coupler; she seems dissatisfied at something: let us observe her.

sp.speaker: COUPLER.
sp.p:
Soh! I am likely to be well rewarded for my services, truly; my suspicions, I find, were but too
just—What! refuse to advance me a paltry sum, when I am upon the point of making him master of a Galloon! But let him look to the consequences, an ungrateful, narrow-minded coxcomb.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: So he is, upon my soul, old lady: it must be my brother you speak of.

sp.speaker: COUPLER.
sp.p: Hah!—stripling, how came you here? What, hast spent all, hey? And art thou come to dun his Lordship for assistance?

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: No;—I want somebody's assistance to cut his Lordship's throat, without the risque of being hang'd for him.

sp.speaker: COUPLER.
sp.p: Egad, sirrah, I could help thee to do him almost as good a turn without the danger of being burnt in the hand for't.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: How—how, old Mischief?

sp.speaker: COUPLER.
sp.p: Why you must know I have done you the kindness to make up a match for your brother.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: I'm very much beholden to you, truly.

sp.speaker: COUPLER.
sp.p: You may before the wedding-day yet: the lady is a great heiress, the match is concluded, the writings are drawn, and his lordship is come hither to put the finishing hand to the business.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: I understand as much.

sp.speaker: COUPLER.
sp.p: Now you must know, stripling, your brother's a knave.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Good.

sp.speaker: COUPLER:
sp.p: He has given me a bond of a thousand pounds for helping him to his fortune, and has promised me as much more in ready money upon the day of the marriage; which, I understand by a friend, he never designs to pay me; and his just now refusing to pay me a part, is a proof of it. If, therefore, you will be a generous young rogue and secure me five thousand pounds, I'll help you to the lady.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: And how the devil wilt thou do that?

sp.speaker: COUPLER.
sp.p: Without the devil's aid, I warrant thee. Thy brother's face not one of the family ever saw; the whole business has been managed by me, and all the letters go thro' my hands. Sir Tunbelly Clumsey, my relation, (for that's the old gentleman's name) is apprized of his lordship's being down here, and expects him to-morrow to receive his daughter's hand; but the Peer, I find, means to bait here a few days longer, to recover the fatigue of his journey, I suppose. Now you shall go to Muddymoat-hall in this place. I'll give you a letter of introduction; and if you don't marry the girl before sun-set, you deserve to be hang'd before morning.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Agreed, agreed; and for thy reward—

sp.speaker: COUPLER.
sp.p: Well, well;—tho' I warrant thou hast not a farthing of money in thy pocket now—no—one may see it in thy face.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Not a souse, by Jupiter.

sp.speaker: COUPLER.
sp.p: Must I advance then?—well, be at my lodgings next door this evening, and I'll see what may be done—We'll sign and seal, and when I have given thee some farther instructions, thou shalt hoist sail and be gone. [Exit Coup.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: So, Lory; Providence thou seest at last takes care of merit: we are in a fair way to be great people.

sp.speaker: LORY.
sp.p: Aye, sir, if the devil don't step between the cup and the lip, as he uses to do.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Why, faith, he has play'd me many a damn'd trick to spoil my fortune; and, egad, I'm almost afraid he's at work about it again now; but if I should tell thee how, thou'dst wonder at me.

sp.speaker: LORY.
sp.p: Indeed, sir, I should not.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: How dost know?

sp.speaker: LORY.
sp.p: Because, sir, I have wondered at you so often, I can wonder at you no more.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: No! what wouldst thou say if a qualm of conscience should spoil my design?

sp.speaker: LORY.
sp.p: I would eat my words, and wonder more than ever!

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p:
Why faith, Lory, tho' I am a young Rakehell,
and have play'd many a rogueish trick, this is so full-grown a cheat, I find I must take pains to come up to't—I have scruples.

sp.speaker: LORY.
sp.p: They are strong symptoms of death. If you find they encrease, sir, pray make your will.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: No, my conscience shan't starve me neither, but thus far I'll listen to it. Before I execute this project, I'll try my brother to the bottom. If he has yet so much humanity about him as to assist me (tho' with a moderate aid) I'll drop my project at his feet, and shew him how I can do for him much more than what I'd ask he'd do for me. This one conclusive trial of him I resolve to make.—
sp.l: Succeed or fail, still victory's my lot,
If I subdue his heart, 'tis well—if not
I will subdue my conscience to my plot.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: HOW do you like these lodgings, my dear? For my part, I am so well pleas'd with them, I shall hardly remove whilst we stay here, if you are satisfied.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: I am satisfied with every thing that pleases you, else I had not come to Scarbro' at all.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: O! a little of the noise and folly of this place will sweeten the pleasures of our retreat; we shall find the charms of our retirement doubled when we return to it.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: That pleasing prospect will be my chiefest entertainment, whilst, much against my will, I engage in those empty pleasures which 'tis so much the fashion to be fond of.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: I own most of them are, indeed, but empty; yet there are delights, of which a private life is destitute, which may divert an honest man, and be a harmless entertainment to a virtuous woman: good musick is one; and truly, (with some small allowance) the plays, I think, may be esteemed another.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: Plays, I must confess, have some small charms, and would have more, would they restrain that loose encouragement to vice, which shocks, if not the virtue of some women, at least the modesty of all.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: But, 'till that reformation can be wholly made, 'twould surely be a pity to exclude the productions of some of our best writers for want of a little wholesome pruning; which might be effected by any one who possessed modesty enough to believe that we should preserve all we can of our deceased authors, at least 'till they are outdone by the living ones.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: What do you think of that you saw last night?

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: To say truth, I did not mind it much; my attention was for some time taken off to admire the workmanship of Nature, in the face of a young lady who sat some distance from me, she was so exquisitely handsome!

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: So exquisitely handsome!

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: Why do you repeat my words, my dear?

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: Because you seem'd to speak them with such pleasure, I thought I might oblige you with their echo.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: Then you are alarm'd, Amanda?

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: It is my duty to be so when you are in danger.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: You are too quick in apprehending for me. I view'd her with a world of admiration, but not one glance of love.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: Take heed of trusting to such nice distinctions. But were your eyes the only things that were inquisitive? Had I been in your place, my tongue, I fancy, had been curious too. I should have ask'd her, where she liv'd (yet still without design) who was she pray?

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: Indeed, I cannot tell.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: You will not tell.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: By all that's sacred then, I did not ask.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: Nor do you know what company was with her?

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: I do not; but why are you so earnest?

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: I thought I had cause.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: But you thought wrong, Amanda; for turn the case, and let it be your story; should you come home and tell me you had seen a handsome man, should I grow jealous because you had eyes?

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: But should I tell you he was exquisitely so, and that I had gazed on him with admiration, should you not think 'twere possible I might go one step further, and enquire his name?

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: (Aside.) She has reason on her side, I have talk'd too much; but I must turn off another way. (To her.) Will you then make no difference, Amanda, between the language of our sex and yours? There is a modesty restrains your tongues, which makes you speak by halves when you commend, but roving flattery gives a loose to ours, which makes us still speak double what we think. You should not, therefore, in so strict a sense, take what I said to her advantage.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: Those flights of flattery, sir, are to our faces only; when women are once out of hearing, you are as modest in your commendations as we are; but I shan't put you to the trouble of farther excuses;—if you please, this business shall rest here, only give me leave to wish, both for your peace and mine, that you may never meet this miracle of beauty more.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: I am content.

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: Madam, there is a lady at the door in a chair, desires to know whether your Ladyship sees company? her name is Berinthia.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: O dear!—'tis a relation I have not seen these five years, pray her to walk in. (Exit Serv.) Here's another beauty for you; she was, when I saw her last, reckoned extremely handsome.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: Don't be jealous now, for I shall gaze upon her too.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: (Aside.) Ha!—by Heav'ns the very woman!

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: (Saluting Amanda.) Dear Amanda, I did not expect to meet with you in Scarbro'.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: Sweet cousin, I'm overjoy'd to see you. (To Lov.) Mr. Loveless, here's a relation and a friend of mine, I desire you'll be better acquainted with.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: (Saluting Berinthia.) If my wife never desires a harder thing, Madam, her request will be easily granted.

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: Sir, my Lord Foppington presents his humble service to you, and desires to know how you do. He's at the next door, and if it be not inconvenient to you, he'll come and wait upon you.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: Give my compliments to his Lordship, and I shall be glad to see him. (Exit Serv.) If you are not acquainted with his Lordship, Madam, you will be entertained with his character.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p:
Now it moves my pity more than my mirth, to
see a man whom Nature has made no sool, be so very industrious to pass for an ass.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: No, there you are wrong, Amanda; you should never bestow your pity upon those who take pains for your contempt; pity those whom Nature abuses, never those who abuse Nature.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Dear Loveless, I am your most humble servant.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: My Lord, I'm your's.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Madam, your Ladyship's very humble slave.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: My Lord, this lady is a relation of my wife's.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: (Saluting her.) The beautifullest race of people upon earth, rat me. Dear Loveless, I am overjoyed that you think of continuing here. I am, stap my vitals. (To. Amanda.) For Gad's sake, Madam, how has your ladyship been able to subsist thus long, under the fatigue of a country life?

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: My life has been very far from that, my Lord, it has been a very quiet one.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Why that's the fatigue I speak of, Madam; for 'tis impossible to be quiet, without thinking; now thinking is to me the greatest fatigue in the world.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: Does not your lordship love reading then?

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Oh, passionately, Madam, but I never think of what I read.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: Why, can your lordship read without thinking?

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: O Lard, can your ladyship pray without devotion, Madam?

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: Well, I must own, I think books the best entertainment in the world.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: I am so much of your ladyship's mind, Madam, that I have a private gallery in town, where I walk sometimes, which is furnished with nothing but books and looking glasses. Madam, I have gilded them, and ranged them so prettily, before Gad, it is the most entertaining thing in the world, to walk and look at them.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: Nay, I love a neat library too, but 'tis, I think, the inside of a book should recommend it most to us.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p:
That, I must confess, I am not altogether so fand of, far to my mind, the inside of a book is to entertain one's self with the forced product of another man's brain. Now I think a man of quality and breeding may be much more diverted with the natural sprauts of his own; but to say the truth, Madam, let a
man love reading never so well, when once he comes to know the tawn, he finds so many better ways of passing away the four-and-twenty hours, that it were ten thousand pities he should consume his time in that. Far example, Madam, now my life, my life, Madam, is a perpetual stream of pleasure, that glides through with such a variety of entertainments, I believe the wisest of our ancestors never had the least conception of any of 'em. I rise, Madam, when in town, about twelve o'clock. I don't rise sooner, because it is the worst thing in the world for the complexion; nat that I pretend to be a beau, but a man must endeavour to look decent, lest he makes so odious a figure in the side-bax, the ladies should be compelled to turn their eyes upon the play; so, at twelve o'clock I say I rise. Naw, if I find it a good day, I resalve to take the exercise of riding, so drink my chocolate, and draw on my boots by two. On my return, I dress; and after dinner, lounge, perhaps to the Opera.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: Your lordship, I suppose, is fond of music?

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: O, passionately, on Tuesdays and Saturdays, provided there is good company, and one is not expected to undergo the fatigue of listening.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: Does your lordship think that the case at the Opera?

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p:
Most certainly, Madam; there is my Lady Tattle, my Lady Prate, my Lady Titter, my Lady Sneer, my Lady Giggle, and my Lady Grin,—these have boxes in the front, and while any favourite
air is singing, are the prettiest company in the waurld, stap my vitals! May'nt we hope for the honour to see you added to our society, Madam?

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: Alas, my Lord, I am the worst company in the world at a concert, I'm so apt to attend to the music.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Why, Madam, that is very pardonable in the country, or at church; but a monstrous inattention in a polite assembly. But I am afraid I tire the company?

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: Not at all; pray go on.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Why then, ladies, there only remains to add, that I generally conclude the evening at one or other of the Clubs, nat that I ever play deep; indeed I have been for some time tied up from losing above five thousand pawnds at a sitting.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: But is'nt your Lordship sometimes obliged to attend the weighty affairs of the nation?

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Sir, as to weighty affairs, I leave them to weighty heads; I never intend mine shall be a burthen to my body.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: Nay, my Lord, but you are a pillar of the state.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: An ornamental pillar, Madam; for sooner than undergo any part of the burthen, rat me, but the whole building should fall to the ground.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: But, my Lord, a fine gentleman spends a great deal of his time in his intrigues; you have given us no account of them yet.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: (Aside.) Soh! She would enquire into my amours, that's jealousy; poor soul! I see she's in love with me. (To her.) Why, Madam, I should have mentioned my intrigues, but I am really afraid I begin to be troublesome with the length of my visit.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: Your lordship is too entertaining to grow troublesome any where.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: (Aside.) That now was as much as if she had said pray make love to me. I'll let her see I'm quick of apprehension. (To her). O Lard, Madam, I had like to have forgot a secret I must needs tell your ladyship. (To Lov.) Ned, you must not be so jealous now as to listen.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: Not I, my Lord, I am too fashionable a husband to pry into the secrets of my wife.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: (To Aman. squeezing her hand) I am in love with you to desperation, strike me speechless!

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: (Giving him a box o' the ear.) Then thus I return your passion,—an impudent fool!

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Gad's curse, Madam, I'm a Peer of the Realm.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: Hey, what the Devil do you affront my wife, Sir? Nay then— (Draws and fight.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: Ah! What has my folly done?—Help! murder! help! Part them, for Heaven's sake.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: (Falling back, and leaning on his sword.) Ah! quite through the body, stap my vitals!

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: (Running to him.) I hope I han't killed the fool, however—bear him up—where's your wound?

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Just thro' the guts.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: Call a surgeon, there—unbutton him quickly.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Ay, pray make haste.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: This mischief you may thank yourself for.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: I may so, love's the Devil, indeed, Ned.

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: Here's Mr. Probe, sir, was just going by the door.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: He's the welcomest man alive.

sp.speaker: PROBE.
sp.p: Stand by, stand by, stand by; pray, Gentlemen, stand by; Lord have mercy upon us! did you never see a man run through the body before? Pray stand by.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Ah! Mr. Probe, I'm a dead man.

sp.speaker: PROBE.
sp.p: A dead man, and I by! I should laugh to see that, egad.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: Prithee, don't stand prating, but look upon his wound.

sp.speaker: PROBE.
sp.p: Why, what if I won't look upon his wound this hour, sir?

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: Why then he'll bleed to death, sir.

sp.speaker: PROBE.
sp.p: Why then I'll fetch him to life again, sir.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: 'Slife! he's run thro' the guts, I tell thee.

sp.speaker: PROBE.
sp.p: I wish he was run thro' the heart, and I should get the more credit by his cure.—Now I hope you are satisfied?—Come, now let me come at him—now let me come at him— (viewing his wound) Oons! what a gash is here!—Why, sir, a man may drive a coach and six horses into your body!

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Oh!

sp.speaker: PROBE.
sp.p: Why, what the devil have you run the gentleman thro' with a scythe?— (aside) A little scratch between the skin and the ribs, that's all.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: Let me see his wound.

sp.speaker: PROBE.
sp.p: Then you shall dress it, Sir—for if any body looks upon it I won't.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: Why thou art the veriest coxcomb I ever saw.

sp.speaker: PROBE.
sp.p: Sir, I am not master of my trade for nothing.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Surgeon!

sp.speaker: PROBE.
sp.p: Sir?

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Are there any hopes?

sp.speaker: PROBE.
sp.p: Hopes! I can't tell—What are you willing to give for a cure?

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Five hundred paunds with pleasure.

sp.speaker: PROBE.
sp.p: Why then perhaps there may be hopes; but we must avoid a further delay—here—help the gentleman into a chair, and carry him to my house presently—that's the properest place— (aside) to bubble him out of his money.—Come, a chair—a chair quickly—there, in with him.— (they put him into a chair)

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Dear Loveless, adieu: if I die, I forgive thee; and if I live, I hope thou wilt do as much by me.—I am sorry you and I should quarrel, but I hope here's an end on't; for if you are satisfied, I am.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: I shall hardly think it worth my prosecuting any farther, so you may be at rest, sir.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Thou art a generous fellow, strike me dumb!— (aside) but thou hast an impertinent wife, stap my vitals!

sp.speaker: PROBE.
sp.p: So—carry him off—carry him off—we shall have him prate himself into a fever by and by—carry him off▪ [Exit. with Ld. Foppington and Probe.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: Now on my knees, my dear, let me ask your pardon for my indiscretion—my own I never shall obtain.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: Oh, there's no harm done—you serv'd him well.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: He did indeed deserve it; but I tremble to think how dear my indiscreet resentment might have cost you.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: O, no matter—never trouble yourself about that.

sp.speaker: TOWNLY.
sp.p: So, so, I'm glad to find you all alive—I met a wounded Peer carrying off—for Heav'ns sake what was the matter?

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: O, a trifle—he would have made love to my wife before my face, so she obliged him with a box o'the ear, and I run him through the body, that was all.

sp.speaker: TOWNLY.
sp.p: Bagatelle on all sides—but pray, Madam, how long has this noble Lord been an humble servant of your's?

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: This is the first I have heard on't—so I suppose 'tis his quality more than his love has brought him into this adventure. He thinks his title an authentic passport to every woman's heart, below the degree of a Peeress.

sp.speaker: TOWNLY.
sp.p: He's coxcomb enough to think any thing; but I would not have you brought into trouble for him.—I hope there's no danger of his life?

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: None at all—he's fallen into the hands of a roguish surgeon, who, I perceive, designs to frighten a little money out of him—but I saw his wound—'tis nothing—he may go to the ball tonight if he pleases.

sp.speaker: TOWNLY.
sp.p: I am glad you have corrected him without farther mischief, or you might have deprived me of the pleasure of executing a plot against his Lordship, which I have been contriving with an old acquaintance of yours.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: Explain—

sp.speaker: TOWNLY.
sp.p: His brother, Tom Fashion, is come down here, and we have it in contemplation to save him the trouble of his intended wedding; but we want your assistance. Tom would have called, but he is preparing for his enterprize, so I promised to bring you to him—so, sir, if these ladies can spare you—

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p:
I'll go with you with all my heart— (aside) —tho' I could wish, methinks, to stay and gaze a little
longer on that creature—Good Gods! how engaging she is—but what have I to do with beauty?—I have already had my portion, and must not covet more.— (To Townly) Come, sir, when you please.

sp.speaker: TOWNLY.
sp.p: Ladies, your servant.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: Mr. Loveless, pray one word with you before you go.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: (to Townly.) I'll overtake you, Colonel. (Exit Townly). What would my dear?

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: Only a woman's foolish question, how do you like my cousin here?

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: Jealous already, Amanda?

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: Not at all—I ask you for another reason.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: (Aside.) Whate'er her reason be, I must not tell her true. (to her). Why, I confess she's handsome—but you must not think I slight your kinswoman, if I own to you, of all the women who may claim that character, she is the last would triumph in my heart.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: I'm satisfied.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: Now tell me why you ask'd?

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: At night I will—Adieu.—

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: (Kissing her. I'm your's— (Exit.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: (Aside.) I'm glad to find he does not like her, for I have a great mind to persuade her to come and live with me.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: (Aside.) Soh! I find my Colonel continues in his airs; there must be something more at the bottom of this than the provocation he pretends from me.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: For Heav'ns sake, Berinthia, tell me what way I shall take to persuade you to come and live with me?

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: Why one way in the world there is—and but one.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: And pray what is that?

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA:
sp.p: It is to assure me—I shall be very welcome.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: If that be all, you shall e'en sleep here tonight.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: To-night!

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: Yes, to-night.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: Why the people where I lodge will think me mad.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: Let 'em think what they please.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p:
Say you so, Amanda?—Why then they shall think what they please—for I'm a young widow, and I care not what any body thinks.—Ah,
Amanda, it's a delicious thing to be a young widow.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: You'll hardly make me think so.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: Puh! because you are in love with your husband—but that is not every woman's case.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: I hope 'twas your's at least.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: Mine, say you?—Now I have a great mind to tell you a lye, but I shall do it so aukwardly, you'd find me out.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: Then e'en speak the truth.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: Shall I?—then, after all, I did love him, Amanda, as a Nun does penance.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: How did you live together?

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: Like man and wife—asunder—he lov'd the country—I the town.—He hawks and hounds—I coaches and equipage.—He eating and drinking—I carding and playing.—He the sound of a horn—I the squeek of a fiddle.—We were dull company at table—worse a-bed: whenever we met we gave one another the spleen, and never agreed but once, which was about lying alone.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: But tell me one thing truly and sincerely—notwithstanding all these jars, did not his death at last extremely trouble you?

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: O yes.—I was forced to wear an odious Widows' band a twelve-month for't.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: Women, I find, have different inclinations:—prithee, Berinthia, instruct me a little farther—for I'm so great a novice, I'm almost asham'd on't.—Not Heav'n knows that what you call intrigues have any charms for me—the practical part of all unlawful love is—

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: O 'tis abominable—but for the speculative, that we must all confess is entertaining enough.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: Pray, be so just then to me, to believe, 'tis with a world of innocence I would enquire whether you think those, we call Women of Reputation, do really escape all other men, as they do those shadows of beaus?

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: O no, Amanda—there are a sort of men make dreadful work amongst 'em—men that may be called the Beaus Antipathy—for they agree in nothing but walking upon two legs. These have brains—the beau has none.—These are in love with their mistress—the beau with himself.—They take care of their reputation—he's industrious to destroy it—They are decent—he's a fop. They are men—he's an ass.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: If this be their character, I fancy we had here e'en now a pattern of 'em both.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: His Lordship and Colonel Townly?

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: The same.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: As for the Lord, he's eminently so; and for the other, I can assure you there's not a man in town who has a better interest with the women, that are worth having an interest with.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: He answers then the opinion I had ever of him—Heav'ns! what a difference there is between a man like him, and that vain nauseous fop, Lord Foppington— (taking her hand) I must acquaint you with a secret, cousin—'tis not that fool alone has talked to me of love.—Townly has been tampering too.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: (Aside) So, so!—here the mystery comes out!—Colonel Townly!—impossible, my dear!

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: 'Tis true, indeed!—tho' he has done it in vain; nor do I think that all the merit of mankind combined, could shake the tender love I bear my husband; yet I will own to you, Berinthia, I did not start at his addresses, as when they came from one whom I contemned.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: (Aside.) O this is better and better—well said innocence!—and you really think, my dear, that nothing could abate your constancy and attachment to your husband?

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: Nothing, I am convinced.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: What if you found he lov'd another woman better?

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: Well!

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: Well!—why were I that thing they call a slighted wife; somebody should run the risk of being that thing they call—a husband.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: O fie, Berinthia, no revenge should ever be taken against a husband—but to wrong his bed is a vengeance, which of all vengeance—

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: Is the sweetest!—ha! ha! ha I—don't I talk madly?

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: Madly indeed!

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: Yet I'm very innocent.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: That I dare swear you are.—I know how to make allowances for your humour—but you resolve then never to marry again?

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: O no!—I resolve I will.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: That I never may.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: You banter me.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: Indeed I don't—but I consider I'm a woman, and form my resolutions accordingly.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: Well, my opinion is, form what resolution you will, matrimony will be the end on't.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: I doubt it—but A Heav'ns!—I have business at home, and am half an hour too late.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: As you are to return with me, I'll just give some orders, and walk with you.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: Well, make haste, and we'll finish this subject as we go. [Exit Amanda.

Ah! poor Amanda, you have led a country life! Well, this discovery is lucky!—base Townly!—at once false to me, and treacherous to his friend! and my innocent, demure, cousin, too!—I have it in my power to be revenged on her, however. Her husband, if I have any skill in countenance, would be as happy in my smiles, as Townly can hope to be in her's.—I'll make the experiment, come what will on't.—The woman who can forgive the being robb'd of a favour'd lover, must be either an ideot or a wanton.

div2.head: SCENE I.
div2.stage: Enter LORD FOPPINGTON and LA VAROLE.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: HEY, fellow—let my vis-a-vis come to the door.

sp.speaker: LA VAROLE.
sp.p: Will your lordship venture so soon to expose yourself to the weather?

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Sir, I will venture as soon as I can to expose myself to the ladies.

sp.speaker: LA VAROLE.
sp.p: I wish your lordship would please to keep house a little longer; I'm affraid your honour does not well consider your wound.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: My wound!—I would not be in eclipse another day, tho' I had as many wounds in my body as I have had in my heart. So mind, Varole, let these cards be left as directed. For this evening I shall wait on my father-in-law, Sir Tunbelly, and I mean to commence my devoirs to the lady, by giving an entertainment at her father's expence; and heark thee, tell Mr. Loveless I request he and his company will honour me with their presence, or I shall think we are not friends.

sp.speaker: LA VAROLE.
sp.p: I will be sure. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Brother, your servant, how do you find yourself to day?

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: So well, that I have ardered my coach to the door;—so there's no danger of death this baut, Tam.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: I'm very glad of it.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON,
sp.p: (Aside.) That I believe's a lye.—Prithee, Tam, tell me one thing—did not your heart cut a caper up to your mauth, when you heard I was ran thro' the bady?

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Why do you think it should?

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Because I remember mine did so when I heard my uncle was shot thro' the head.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: It then did very ill.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Prithee, why so?

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Because he used you very well.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Well!—Naw, strike me dumb, he starv'd me—he has let me want a thausand women, for want of a thausand pound.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Then he hinder'd you from making a great many ill bargains—for I think no woman worth money that will take money.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: If I was a younger brother, I should think so too.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Then you are seldom much in love?

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Never, stap my vitals.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Why then did you make all this bustle about Amanda?

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Because she was a woman of an insolent virtue—and I thought myself piqu'd in honour to debauch her.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: (Aside.) Very well. Here's a rare fellow for you, to have the spending of five thousand pounds a year. But now for my business with him.—Brother, tho' I know to talk of business (especially of money) is a theme not quite so entertaining to you as that of the ladies, my necessities are such, I hope you'll have patience to hear me.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: The greatness of your necessities, Tam, is the worst argument in the warld for your being patiently heard. I do believe you are going to make a very good speech, but strike me dumb, it has the worst beginning of any speech I have heard this twelvemonth.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: I'm sorry you think so.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: I do believe thou art—but come, let's know the affair quickly.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Why then, my case in a word is this.—The necessary expences of my travels have so much exceeded the wretched income of my annuity, that I have been forced to mortgage it for five hundred pounds, which is spent. So unless you are so kind as to assist me in redeeming it, I know no remedy but to take a purse.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Why, faith, Tam, to give you my sense of the thing, I do think taking a purse the best remedy in the warld—for if you succeed you are relieved that way, if you are taken—you are relieved t'other.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: I'm glad to see you are in so pleasant a humour; I hope I shall find the effects on't.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Why, do you then really think it a reasonable thing that I should give you five hundred pawnds?

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: I do not ask it as a due, brother, I am willing to receive it as a favour.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p:
Then thou art willing to receive it any how, strike me speechless.—But these are d—n'd times to give money in; taxes are so great, repairs so exorbitant, tenants such rogues, and bouquets so dear, that the Devil take me, I am reduced to to that extremity in my cash, I have been forced to retrench in that one article of sweet pawder,
till I have brought it dawn to five guineas a maunth—now judge, Tam, whether I can spare you five hundred pawnds?

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: If you can't I must starve, that's all. (Aside.) Damn him.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: All I can say is, you should have been a better husband.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Ouns!—If you can't live upon ten thousand a year, how do you think I should do't upon two hundred?

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Don't be in a passion, Tam, for passion is the most unbecoming thing in the warld—to the face. Look you, I don't love to say any thing to you to make you melancholy, but upon this occasion I must take leave to put you in mind, that a running-horse does require more attendance than a coach-horse.—Nature has made some difference 'twixt you and me.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Yes.—She has made you older. (Aside.) Plague take her.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: That is not all, Tam.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Why, what is there else?

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: (Looking first upon himself and then upon his brother.) Ask the ladies.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p:
Why, thou Essence-bottle, thou Musk Cat,—dost
thou then think thou hast any advantage over me but what fortune has given thee?

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: I do, stap my vitals.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Now, by all that's great and powerful thou art the Prince of Coxcombs.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Sir, I am proud at being at the head of so prevailing a party.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Will nothing then provoke thee?—Draw, Coward.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Look you, Tam, you know I have always taken you for a mighty dull fellow, and here is one of the foolishest plats broke out, that I have seen a lang time. Your poverty makes life so burthen-some to you, you would provoke me to a quarrel, in hopes either to slip through my lungs into my estate, or to get yourself run thro' the guts, to put an end to your pain, but I will disappoint you in both your designs; far with the temper of a Philasapher, and the discretion of a statesman—I shall leave the room with my sword in the scabbard. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: So! farewell brother; and now conscience I defy thee.—Lory!

sp.speaker: LORY.
sp.p: Sir?

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Here's rare news, Lory, his Lordship has given me a pill has purged off all my scruples.

sp.speaker: LORY.
sp.p: Then my heart's at ease again. For I have been in a lamentable fright, sir, ever since your conscience had the impudence to intrude into your company.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Be at peace; it will come there no more, my brother has given it a wring by the nose, and I have kick'd it down stairs. So run away to the inn, get the chaise ready quickly, and bring it to dame Coupler's without a moment's delay.

sp.speaker: LORY.
sp.p: Then, sir, you are going striaght about the fortune?

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: I am.—Away—fly, Lory.

sp.speaker: LORY.
sp.p: The happiest day I ever saw. I'm upon the wing already.

div2.head: SCENE, A GARDEN.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: Is my wife within?

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: No, sir, she has been gone out this half hour.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p:
Well, leave me. (Exit Servant.) How strangely does my mind run on this widow—never
was my heart so suddenly seiz'd on before—that my wife should pick out her, of all woman-kind, to be her playfellow.—But what fate does, let fate answer for—I sought it not—soh!—by heav'ns!—here she comes.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: What makes you look so thoughtful, Sir? I hope you are not ill.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: I was debating, madam, whether I was so or not, and that was it which made me look so thoughtful.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: Is it then so hard a matter to decide?—I thought all people were acquainted with their own bodies, tho' few people know their own minds.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: What if the distemper I suspect be in the mind?

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: Why then I'll undertake to prescribe you a cure.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: Alas! you undertake you know not what.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: So far at least then you allow me to be a Physician.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: Nay, I'll allow you to be so yet farther, for I have reason to believe, should I put myself into your hands, you would increase my distemper.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: Oh, you might betray my complaints to my wife.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: And so lose all my practice.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: Will you then keep my secret?

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: I will.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: I'm satisfied. Now hear my symptoms, and give me your advice. The first were these when I saw you at the play; a random glance you threw, at first alarm'd me. I could not turn my eyes from whence the danger came—I gaz'd upon you till my heart began to pant—nay, even now on your approaching me, my illness is so increas'd, that if you do not help me I shall, whilst you look on, consume to Ashes. (Taking her hand.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: (Breaking from him.) O Lord let me go, 'tis the plague, and we shall be infected.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: Then we'll die together, my charming angel.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: O Gad! the devil's in you. Lord, let me go—here's somebody coming.

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: Sir, my lady's come home, and desires to speak with you.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: Tell her I'm coming. (Exit Servant).—(To Berinthia) But before I go, one glass of nectar to drink her health.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: Stand off, or I shall hate you, by heavens.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: (Kissing her.) In matters of love, a woman's oath is no more to be minded than a man's. (Exit Lov.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: Um!

sp.speaker: TOWNLY.
sp.p: Soh! what's here—Berinthia and Loveless—and in such close conversation!—I cannot now wonder at her indifference in excusing herself to me!—O rare woman,—well then, let Loveless look to his wife, 'twill be but the retort courteous on both sides.— (To Berinthia.) Your servant, Madam, I need not ask you how you do, you have got so good a colour.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: No better than I used to have, I suppose.

sp.speaker: TOWNLY.
sp.p: A little more blood in your cheeks.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: I have been walking!

sp.speaker: TOWNLY.
sp.p: Is that all? Pray was it Mr. Loveless went from here just now?

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: O yes—he has been walking with me.

sp.speaker: TOWNLY.
sp.p: He has!

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: Upon my word I think he is a very agreeable man!—and there is certainly something particularly insinuating in his address!

sp.speaker: TOWNLY.
sp.p: So! so! she has n't even the modesty to dissemble! Pray, madam, may I, without impertinence, trouble you with a few serious questions?

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: As many as you please; but pray let them be as little serious as possible.

sp.speaker: TOWNLY.
sp.p: Is it not near two years since I have presumed to address you?

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: I don't know exactly—but it has been a tedious long time.

sp.speaker: TOWNLY.
sp.p: Have I not, during that period, had every reason to believe that my assiduities were far from being unacceptable?

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: Why, to do you justice, you have been extremely troublesome—and I confess I have been more civil to you than you deserved.

sp.speaker: TOWNLY.
sp.p: Did I not come to this place at your express desire? and for no purpose but the honour of meeting you?—and after wasting a month in disappointment, have you condescended to explain, or in the slightest way apologize, for your conduct?

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: O heav'ns! apologize for my conduct!—apologise to you!—O you barbarian!—But pray now, my good serious Colonel, have you any thing more to add?

sp.speaker: TOWNLY.
sp.p: Nothing, madam, but that after such behaviour I am less surpris'd at what I saw just now; it is not very wonderful that the woman who can trifle with the delicate addresses of an honourable lover, should be found coquetting with the husband of her friend.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: Very true—no more wonderful than it was for this honourable lover to divert himself in the absence of this coquet, with endeavouring to seduce his friend's wife! O Colonel, Colonel, don't talk of honor or your friend, for heav'ns sake.

sp.speaker: TOWNLY.
sp.p: S'death! how came she to suspect this.—Really madam, I don't understand you.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: Nay—nay—you saw I did not pretend to misunderstand you.—But here comes the Lady—perhaps you would be glad to be left with her for an explanation.

sp.speaker: TOWNLY.
sp.p: O madam, this recrimination is a poor resource, and to convince you how much you are mistaken, I beg leave to decline the happiness you propose me.—Madam, your servant.

div2.stage: Enter AMANDA. (TOWNLY whispers AMANDA, and exit.)

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: He carries it off well however—upon my word—very well!—how tenderly they part!—So, cousin—I hope you have not been chiding your admirer for being with me—I assure you we have been talking of you.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: Fie, Berinthia!—my admirer—will you never learn to talk in earnest of any thing?

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: Why this shall be in earnest, if you please; for my part I only tell you matter of fact.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: I'm sure there's so much jest and earnest in what you say to me on this subject, I scarce know how to take it.—I have just parted with Mr. Loveless—perhaps it is my fancy, but I think there is an alteration in his manner, which alarms me.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: And so you are jealous? is that all?

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: That all!—is jealousy then nothing?

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: It should be nothing, if I were in your case.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: Why what would you do?

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: I'd cure myself.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p:
Care as little for my husband as he did for me.
Look you, Amanda, you may build castles in the air, and fume, and fret, and grow thin, and lean, and pale, and ugly, if you please, but I tell you, no man worth having is true to his wife, or ever was, or ever will be so.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: Do you then really think he's false to me? for I did not suspect him.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: Think so!—I am sure of it.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: You are sure on't?

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: Positively—he fell in love at the play.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: Right—the very same—but who could have told you this?

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: Um—O—Townly!—I suppose your husband has made him his confidant.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: O base Loveless!—and what did Townly say on't?

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: So, so—why should she ask that?— (aside)—say!—why he abused Loveless extremely, and said all the tender things of you in the world.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: Did he?—Oh! my heart!—I'm very ill—I must go to the chamber—dear Berinthia, don't leave me a moment. (Exit.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p:
No—don't fear.—So—there is certainly some affection on her side at least, towards Townly.
If it prove so, and her agreeable husband perseveres—Heav'n send me resolution!—well—how this business will end I know not—but I seem to be in as fair a way to lose my gallant Colonel, as a boy is to be a rogue, when he's put clerk to an attorney. [Exit.

div2.head: SCENE, a Country House.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: So—here's our inheritance, Lory, if we can but get into possession—but methinks the seat of our family looks like Noah's ark, as if the chief part on't were designed for the fowls of the air, and the beasts of the field.

sp.speaker: LORY.
sp.p: Pray, sir, don't let your head run upon the orders of building here—get but the heiress, let the devil take the house.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Get but the house! let the devil take the heiress, I say—but come, we have no time to squander, knock at the door— [Lory knocks two or three times.
What the devil have they got no ears in this house?—knock harder.

sp.speaker: LORY.
sp.p: I'gad, sir, this will prove some inchanted castle—we shall have the giant come out by and by with his club, and beat our brains out. (knocks again.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Hush—they come— (from within) who is there?

sp.speaker: LORY.
sp.p: Open the door and see—is that your country breeding?—

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: (within) Ay, but two words to that bargain—Tummas, is the blunderbuss prim'd?

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Ouns! give 'em good words Lory—or we shall be shot here a fortune catching.

sp.speaker: LORY.
sp.p: Egad sir, I think you're in the right on't—ho!—Mr. what d'ye callum—will you please to let us in? or are we to be left to grow like willows by your moat side? (Servant appears at the window with a blunderbuss)

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: Weel naw, what's ya're business?

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Nothing, sir, but to wait upon Sir Tunbelly, with your leave.

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: To weat upon Sir Tunbelly?—why you'll find that's just as Sir Tunbelly pleases.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: But will you do me the favour, sir, to know whether Sir Tunbelly pleases or not?

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: Why look you d'ye see, with good words much may be done.—Ralph, go thy waes, and ask Sir Tunbelly if he pleases to be waited upon—and dost hear? call to nurse that she may lock up Miss Hoyden before the geats open.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: D'ye hear that Lory?

div2.stage: Enter SIR TUNBELLY, with Servants, armed with guns, clubs, pitchforks, &c.

sp.speaker: LORY.
sp.p: O (Running behind his master) O Lord, O Lord, Lord, we are both dead men.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Take heed fool, thy fear will ruin us.

sp.speaker: IORY.
sp.p: My fear, sir, 'sdeath, sir, I fear nothing— (aside) would I were well up to the chin in a horse pond.

sp.speaker: SIR TUNBELLY.
sp.p: Who is it here has any business with me?

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Sir, 'tis I, if your name be Sir Tunbelly Clumsey?

sp.speaker: SIR TUNBELLY.
sp.p: Sir, my name is Sir Tunbelly Clumsy, whether you have any business with me or not—so you see I am not asham'd of my name, nor my face either.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Sir, you have no cause that I know of.

sp.speaker: SIR TUNBELLY.
sp.p: Sir, if you have no cause either, I desire to know who you are; for 'till I know your name, I shan't ask you to come into my house: and when I do know your name, 'tis six to four I don't ask you then.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: (Giving him a Letter) Sir, I hope you'll find this letter an authentic passport.

sp.speaker: SIR TUNBELLY.
sp.p:
Cod's my life, from Mrs. Coupler.—I ask your Lordship's pardon ten thousand times— (to his Servant) —Here, run in a doors quickly; get a Scotch
coal fire in the great parlour—set all the Turkey work chairs in their places; get the brass candlesticks out, and be sure stick the socket full of laurel, run— (turning to Young Fashion) My Lord, I ask your Lordship's pardon— (to Servant) and do you hear, run away to nurse, bid her let Miss Hoyden loose again. [Exit Servant.

(To Young Fashion) I hope your honour will excuse the disorder of my family—we are not used to receive men of your Lordship's great quality every day—pray where are your coaches and servants, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Sir, that I might give you and your daughter a proof how impatient I am to be nearer akin to you, I left my equipage to follow me, and came away post with only one servant.

sp.speaker: SIR TUNBELLY.
sp.p: Your Lordship does me too much honour—It was exposing your person to too much fatigue and danger, I protest it was—but my daughter shall endeavour to make you what amends she can—and tho' I say it, that should not say it, Hoyden has charms.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Sir, I am not a stranger to them, tho' I am to her: common fame has done her justice.

sp.speaker: SIR TUNBELLY.
sp.p: My Lord, I am common Fame's very grateful humble servant.—My Lord, my girl's young—Hoyden is young, my Lord; but this I must say for her, what she wants in art, she has by nature—what she wants in experience, she has in breeding—and what's wanting in her age, is made good in her constitution—so pray, my Lord, walk in; pray, my Lord, walk in.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Sir, I wait upon you. [Ex. thro' the gate.

sp.speaker: MISS.
sp.p: Sure, nobody was ever used as I am. I know well enough what other girls do, for all they think to make a fool of me. It's well I have a husband a-coming, or I'cod I'd marry the baker, I would so.—Nobody can knock at the gate, but presently I must be lock'd up—and here's the young greyhound can run loose about the house all the day long, so she can.—'Tis very well—

sp.speaker: NURSE.
sp.p: Miss Hoyden, Miss, Miss, Miss, Miss Hoyden!

sp.speaker: MISS.
sp.p: Well, what do you make such a noise for, ha?—what do you din a body's ears for?—can't one be at quiet for you?

sp.speaker: NURSE.
sp.p: What do I din your ears for?—here's one come will din your ears for you.

sp.speaker: MISS.
sp.p: What care I who's come?—I care not a fig who comes, nor who goes, as long as I must be lock'd up like the ale cellar.

sp.speaker: NURSE.
sp.p: That, Miss, is for fear you should be drank before you are ripe.

sp.speaker: MISS.
sp.p: O don't you trouble your head about that, I'm as ripe as you, though not so mellow.

sp.speaker: NURSE.
sp.p: Very well—now I have a good mind to lock you up again, and not let you see my Lord to-night.

sp.speaker: MISS.
sp.p: My Lord! why is my husband come?

sp.speaker: NURSE.
sp.p: Yes, marry is he, and a goodly person too.

sp.speaker: MISS.
sp.p: (Hugging Nurse) O my dear nurse, forgive me this once, and I'll never misuse you again; no, if I do, you shall give me three thumps on the back, and a great pinch by the cheek.

sp.speaker: NURSE.
sp.p: Ah! the poor thing, see how it melts, its as full of good nature as an egg's full of meat.

sp.speaker: MISS.
sp.p: But my dear Nurse, don't lie now, is he come by your troth?

sp.speaker: NURSE.
sp.p: Yes, by my truly is he.

sp.speaker: MISS.
sp.p: O Lord! I'll go and put on my laced tucker, tho' I'm lock'd up a month for't. [Exit running.

sp.speaker: NURSE.
sp.p: WELL, Miss, how do you like your husband that is to be?

sp.speaker: MISS.
sp.p: O Lord, Nurse, I'm so overjoy'd, I can scarce contain myself.

sp.speaker: NURSE.
sp.p: O but you must have a care of being too fond, for men now-a-days, hate a woman that loves 'em.

sp.speaker: MISS.
sp.p: Love him! Why do you think I love him, Nurse? I'cod, I would not care if he was hang'd, so I were but once married to him.—No, that which pleases me, is to think what work I'll make when I get to London; for when I am a wife and a Lady both, I'cod I'll flaunt it with the best of 'em. Aye, and I shall have money enough to do so too, Nurse.

sp.speaker: NURSE.
sp.p:
Ah! there's no knowing that Miss, for though these Lords have a power of wealth, indeed, yet, as I have heard say, they give it all to their sluts and their trulls, who joggle it about in their
coaches, with a murrain to 'em, whilst poor Madam sits sighing and wishing, and has not a spare half crown to buy her a Practice of Piety.

sp.speaker: MISS.
sp.p: O, but for that, don't deceive yourself, Nurse, for this I must say of my Lord, he's as free as an open house at Christmas. For this very morning he told me, I should have six hundred a year to buy pins. Now, Nurse, if he gives me six hundred a year to buy pins, what do you think he'll give me to buy fine petticoats?

sp.speaker: NURSE.
sp.p: Ah, my dearest, he deceives thee fouly, and he's no better than a rogue for his pains. These Londoners have got a gibberage with 'em, would confound a gipsey. That which they call pinmoney, is to buy their wives every thing in the versal world, down to their very shoe-knots.—Nay, I have heard folks say, that some ladies, if they will have gallants, as they call 'em, are forced to find them out of their pin-money too. But, look, look, if his Honor be not coming to you.—Now, if I were sure you would behave yourself handsomely, and not disgrace me that have brought you up, I'd leave you alone together.

sp.speaker: MISS.
sp.p: That's my best Nurse, do as you'd be done by—trust us together this once, and if I don't shew my breeding, may I never be married but die an old maid.

sp.speaker: NURSE.
sp.p: Well, this once I'll venture you.—But if you disparage me—

sp.speaker: MISS.
sp.p: Never fear. [Exit Nurse.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Your servant, Madam, I'm glad to find you alone, for I have something of importance to speak to you about.

sp.speaker: MISS.
sp.p: Sir, (my Lord, I meant) you may speak to me about what you please, I shall give you a civil answer.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: You give me so obliging a one, it encourages me to tell you in a few words, what I think both for your interest and mine. Your father, I suppose you know, has resolved to make me happy in being your husband, and I hope I may depend on your consent to perform what he desires.

sp.speaker: MISS.
sp.p: Sir, I never disobey my father in any thing but eating green gooseberries.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: So good a daughter must needs be an admirable wife.—I am therefore impatient till you are mine, and hope you will so far consider the violence of my love, that you won't have the cruelty to defer my happiness so long as your father designs it.

sp.speaker: MISS.
sp.p: Pray, my Lord, how long is that?

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Madam—a thousand years—a whole week.

sp.speaker: MISS.
sp.p: A week!—Why I shall be an old woman by that time.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: And I an old man.

sp.speaker: MISS.
sp.p: Why I thought it was to be to-morrow morning, as soon as I was up. I'm sure nurse told me so.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: And it shall be to-morrow morning, if you'll consent?

sp.speaker: MISS.
sp.p: If I'll consent! Why I thought I was to obey you as my husband?

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: That's when we are married. Till then I'm to obey you.

sp.speaker: MISS.
sp.p: Why then if we are to take it by turns, it's the same thing. I'll obey you now, and when we are married you shall obey me.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: With all my heart. But I doubt we must get Nurse on our side, or we shall hardly prevail with the Chaplain.

sp.speaker: MISS.
sp.p: No more we shan't indeed, for he loves her better than he loves his pulpit, and would always be a-preaching to her by his good will.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Why then, my dear, if you'll call her hither, we'll try to persuade her presently.

sp.speaker: MISS.
sp.p: O Lord, I can tell you a way how to perswade her to any thing.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: How's that?

sp.speaker: MISS.
sp.p: Why tell her she's a handsome, comely woman, and give her half-a-crown.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Nay, if that will do, she shall have half a score of them.

sp.speaker: MISS.
sp.p: O Gemini, for half that she'd marry you herself.—I'll run and call her. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Soh, matters go swimmingly. This is a rare girl I'faith. I shall have a fine time on't with her at London. But no matter—she brings me an estate will afford me a separate maintenance.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: So, Lory, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: LORY.
sp.p: Here, Sir; an intercepted packet from the enemy—your brother's postillion brought it—I knew the livery; pretended to be a servant of Sir Tunbelly's, and so got possession of the letter.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p:
(Looking at it) Ouns!—He tells Sir Tunbelly here, that he will be with him this evening, with a large party
to supper,—'egad! I must marry the girl directly.

sp.speaker: LORY.
sp.p: O Zounds, Sir, directly to be sure! Here she comes. [Exit Lory.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: And the old Jesabel with her. She has a thorough procuring countenance, however.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: How do you do, Mrs. Nurse?—I desired your young lady would give me leave to see you, that I might thank you for your extraordinary care and conduct in her education; pray accept of this small acknowledgement for it at present, and depend upon my farther kindness when I shall be that happy thing her husband.

sp.speaker: NURSE.
