sp.p: (Aside.) Gold by Maakins!—Your Honour's goodness is too great. Alas! all I can boast of is, I gave her pure good milk, and so your Honour would have said, an you had seen how-the poor thing thrived—and how it would look up in my face—and crow and laugh it would!

sp.speaker: MISS.
sp.p:
(To Nurse, taking her angrily aside.) Pray one word with you. Prithee, Nurse, don't stand ripping up old stories, to make one ashamed before one's love; do you think such a fine, proper gentleman as he is, cares for a fiddle-come tale of a child? If you have a mind to make him have a good opinion of a woman, don't tell him what one did then, tell him what one can do now. (To him.) I hope your Honour will
excuse my mis-manners, to whisper before you, it was only to give some orders about the family.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: O every thing, Madam, is to give way to business; besides, good housewisery is a very commendable quality in a young lady.

sp.speaker: MISS.
sp.p: Pary, Sir, are young ladies good housewives at London town? Do they darn their own linnen.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: O no;—they study how to spend money, not to save.

sp.speaker: MISS.
sp.p: I'cod, I don't know but that may be better sport, ha, Nurse!

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Well, you shall have your choice when you come there.

sp.speaker: MISS.
sp.p: Shall I?—then by my troth I'll get there as fast as I can. (To Nurse.) His Honour desires you'll be so kind, as to let us be married to-morrow.

sp.speaker: NURSE.
sp.p: To-morrow, my dear Madam?

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Aye faith, Nurse, you may well be surprised at Miss's wanting to put it off so long—to-morrow! no, no,—'tis now, this very hour, I would have the ceremony perform'd.

sp.speaker: MISS.
sp.p: I'cod with all my heart.

sp.speaker: NURSE.
sp.p: O mercy, worse and worse.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Yes, sweet Nurse, now, and privately. For all things being signed and sealed, why should Sir Tunbelly make us stay a week for a wedding dinner?

sp.speaker: NURSE.
sp.p: But if you should be married now, what will you do when Sir Tunbelly calls for you to be wedded?

sp.speaker: MISS.
sp.p: Why then we will be married again.

sp.speaker: NURSE.
sp.p: What twice, my child!

sp.speaker: MISS.
sp.p: I'cod, I don't care how often I'm married, not I.

sp.speaker: NURSE.
sp.p: Well—I'm such a tender hearted fool, I find I can refuse you nothing. So you shall e'en follow your own inventions.

sp.speaker: MISS.
sp.p: Shall I?— (Aside.) O Lord I could leap over the Moon.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Dear Nurse, this goodness of your's shan't go unrewarded. But now you must employ your power with the Chaplain, that he may do his friendly office too, and then we shall be all happy. Do you think you can prevail with him?

sp.speaker: NURSE.
sp.p: Prevail with him!—Or he shall never prevail with me, I can tell him that.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p:
I'm glad to hear it; however, to strengthen
your interest with him, you may let him know, I have several fat livings in my gift, and that the first that salls shall be in your disposal.

sp.speaker: NURSE.
sp.p: Nay then, I'll make him marry more folks than one, I'll promise him.

sp.speaker: MISS.
sp.p: Faith do, Nurse, make him marry you too, I'm sure he'll do't for a fat living.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Well, Nurse, while you go and settle matters with him, your lady and I will go and take a walk in the garden. [Exit Nurse.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: (Giving her his hand.) Come, Madam, dare you venture yourself alone with me?

sp.speaker: MISS.
sp.p: O dear, yes, Sir, I don't think you'll do any thing to me I need be afraid on. [Exeunt.

sp.speaker: MAID.
sp.p: If you please, Madam, only to say whether you'll have me buy them or not?

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: Yes—no—go—Teazer!—I care not what you do—prithee leave me. [Exit Maid.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: What, in the name of Jove's the matter with you?

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: The matter, Berinthia? I'm almost mad; I'm plagued to death.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: Who is it that plagues you?

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: Who do you think should plague a wife, but her husband?

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: O ho! is it come to that?—we shall have you wish yourself a widow, by and bye.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: Would I were any thing but what I am!—a base, ungrateful man, to use me thus!

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: What, has he given you fresh reason to suspect his wandering?

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: Every hour gives me reason.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: And yet, Amanda, you perhaps at this moment cause in another's breast the same tormenting doubts and jealousies which you feel so sensibly yourself.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: Heaven knows I would not!

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p:
Why, you can't tell but there may be some one as tenderly attached to Townly, whom you
boast of as your conquest, as you can be to your husband.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: I'm sure I never encouraged his pretensions.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: Pshaw! Pshaw!—No sensible man ever perseveres to love, without encouragement. Why have you not treated him as you have Lord Foppington?

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: Because he has not presum'd so far. But let us drop the subject. Men, not women, are riddles. Mr. Loveless now follows some flirt for variety, whom I'm sure he does not like so well as he does me.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: That's more than you know, Madam.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: Why, do you know the ugly thing?

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: I think I can guess at the person—but she's no such ugly thing neither.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: Is she very handsome?

sp.speaker: BERINNHIA.
sp.p: Truly I think so.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: Whate'er she be, I'm sure he does not like her well enough to bestow any thing more than a little outward gallantry upon her.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p:
(Aside.) Outward gallantry.—I can't bear this.—Come, come, don't you be too secure, Amanda; while you suffer Townly to imagine that you do not detest him for his designs on you, you have no right
to complain that your husband is engaged elsewhere. But here comes the person we were speaking of.

sp.speaker: TOWNLY.
sp.p: Ladies, as I come uninvited, I beg, if I intrude you will use the same freedom in turning me out again.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: I believe, sir, it is near the time Mr. Loveless said he would be at home. He talked of accepting of Lord Foppington's invitation to sup at Sir Tunbelly Clumsey's.

sp.speaker: TOWNLY.
sp.p: His Lordship has done me the honor to invite me also. If you'll let me escort you, I'll let you into a mystery as me go, in which you must play a part when we arrive.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: But we have two hours yet to spare—the carriages are not ordered 'till eight—and it is not a five minutes drive. So, Cousin, let us keep the Colonel to play piquet with us, till Mr. Loveless comes home.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: As you please, Madam, but you know I have a letter to write.

sp.speaker: TOWNLY.
sp.p: Madam, you know you may command me, tho' I'm a very wretched gamester.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p:
O, you play well enough to lose your money, and that's all the ladies require—and
so without any more ceremony, let us go into the next room and call for cards and candles.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: So—thus far all's well—I have got into her dressing-room, and it being dusk, I think nobody has perceived me steal into the house. I heard Berinthia tell my wife she had some particular letters to write this evening, before we went to Sir Tunbelly's, and here are the implements for correspondence—how shall I muster up assurance to shew myself when she comes?—I think she has given me encouragement—and to do my impudence justice, I have made the most of it.—I hear a door open and some one coming; if it should be my wife, what the Devil should I say?—I believe she mistrusts me, and by my life I don't deserve her tenderness; however I am determined to reform, tho' not yet. Hah!—Berinthia—so I'll step in here till I see what sort of humour she is in. [Goes into the Closet.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p:
Was ever so provoking a situation!—To think
I should sit and hear him compliment Amanda to my face!—I have lost all patience with them both. I would not for something have Loveless know what temper of mind they have piqued me into, yet I can't bear to leave them together. No—I'll put my papers away, and return, to disappoint them. (Goes to the closet.) O Lord! a ghost! a ghost! a ghost!

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: Peace, my Angel—it's no ghost—but one worth a hundred spirits.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: How, sir, have you had the insolence to presume to—run in again—here's somebody coming.

sp.speaker: MAID.
sp.p: O Lord, Ma'am, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: O Heav'ns I'm almost frightened out of my wits!—I thought verily I had seen a ghost, and 'twas nothing but a black hood pin'd against the wall.—You may go again, I am the fearfulest fool! [Exit Maid.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: Is the coast clear?

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: The coast clear!—Upon my word I wonder at your assurance!

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: Why then you wonder before I have given you a proof of it. But where's my wife?

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: At cards.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: With whom?

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: With Townly.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: Then we are safe enough.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: You are so!—Some husbands would be of another mind were he at cards with their wives.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: And they'd be in the right on't too—but I dare trust mine.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: Indeed!—And she, I doubt not, has the same confidence in you. Yet do you think she'd be content to come and find you here?

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: 'Egad, as you say, that's true—then for fear she should come, hadn't we better go into the next room out of her way?

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: What—in the dark?

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: Aye—or with a light, which you please.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: You are certainly very impudent.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: Nay then—let me conduct you, my Angel.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: Hold, hold, you are mistaken in your Angel, I assure you.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: I hope not, for by this hand I swear.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: Come, come, let go my hand, or I shall hate you, I'll cry out as I live.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: Impossible!—you cannot be so cruel.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: Ha!—here's some one coming—be gone instantly.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: Will you promise to return if I remain here?

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: Never trust myself in a room with you again while I live.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: But I have something particular to communicate to you.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: Well, well, before we go to Sir Tunbelly's I'll walk upon the lawn. If you are fond of a Moon-light evening, you will find me there.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: E'faith, they're coming here now.—I take you at your word. [Exit Loveless into the Closet.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p:
'Tis Amanda, as I live.—I hope she has not
heard his voice. Tho' I mean she should have er share of jealousy in turn.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: Berinthia, why did you leave me?

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: I thought I only spoil'd your party.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: Since you have been gone, Townly has attempted to renew his importunities.—I must break with him—for I cannot venture to acquaint Mr. Loveless with his conduct.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: O no—Mr. Loveless mustnt know of it by any means.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: O not for the world.—I wish, Berinthia, you would undertake to speak to Townly on the subject.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: Upon my word it would be a very pleasant subject for me to talk to him on.—But come—let us go back,—and you may depend on't I'll not leave you together again, if I can help it.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p:
Soh—so!—a pretty piece of business I have over-heard—Townly makes love to my wife—and I'm not to know it for the world—I must
enquire into this—and, by Heav'n, if I find that Amanda has in the smallest degree—Yet what have I been at here?—O s'death! that's no rule.
sp.l: That wife alone, unsullied credit wins,
Whose virtues can atone her husband's sins;
Thus while the man has other nymphs in view,
It suits the woman to be doubly true.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: NOW, does she mean to make a fool of me, or not?—I shan't wait much longer, for my wife will soon be enquiring for me to set out on our supping party.—Suspence is at all times the devil—but of all modes of suspence, the watching for a loitering mistress is the worst—but let me accuse her no longer—she approaches with one smile to o'erpay the anxiety of a year.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: O Berinthia, what a world of kindness are you in my debt!—had you staid five minutes longer—

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: You would have been gone, I suppose.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: (Aside) Egad she's right enough.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: And I assure you 'twas ten to one that I came at all. In short, I begin to think you are too dangerous a Being to trifle with; and as I shall probably only make a fool of you at last, I believe we had better let matters rest as they are.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS,
sp.p: You cannot mean it sure?

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: No!—why do you think you are really so irresistable, and master of so much address, as to deprive a woman of her senses in a few days acquaintance?

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: O, no, Madam; 'tis only by your preserving your senses that I can hope to be admitted into your favour—your taste, judgment, and discernment, are what I build my hopes on.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: Very modest upon my word—and it certainly follows, that the greatest proof I can give of my possessing those qualities, would be my admiring Mr. Loveless!

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: O that were so cold a proof—

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: What shall I do more?—esteem you?

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: O, no—worse and worse.—Can you behold a man, whose every faculty your attractions have engrossed—whose whole soul, as by enchantment, you have seiz'd on—can you see him tremble at your feet, and talk of so poor a return as your esteem!

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: What more would you have me give to a married man?

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: How doubly cruel to remind me of misfortunes!

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: A misfortune to be married to so charming a woman as Amanda!

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: I grant all her merit, but—'sdeath, now see what you have done by talking of her—she's here by all that's unlucky.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: O Ged, we had both better get out of the way, for I should feel as aukward to meet her as you.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: Aye—but if I mistake not, I see Townly coming this way also—I must see a little into this matter. (steps aside)

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: O, if that's your intention—I am no woman if suffer myself to be outdone in curiosity. (goes on the other side.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: Mr. Loveless come home and walking on the awn!—I will not suffer him to walk so late, tho' perhaps it is to shew his neglect of me—Mr. Loveless—ha!—Townly again!—how I am persecuted!

sp.speaker: TOWNLY.
sp.p: Madam, you seem disturbed!

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: Sir, I have reason.

sp.speaker: TOWNLY.
sp.p: Whatever be the cause, I would to Heaven it were in my power to bear the pain, or to remove the malady.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: Your interference can only add to my distress.

sp.speaker: TOWNLY.
sp.p: Ah! Madam, if it be the sting of unrequited love you suffer from, seek for your remedy in revenge—weigh well the strength and beauty of your charms, and rouse up that spirit a woman ought to bear—disdain the false embraces of a husband—see at your feet a real lover—his zeal may give him title to your pity, altho' his merit cannot claim your love!

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: (Aside.) So, so, very fine, e'faith!

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: Why do you presume to talk to me thus?—is this your friendship to Mr. Loveless?—I perceive you will compel me at last to acquaint him with your treachery.

sp.speaker: TOWNLY.
sp.p: He could not upbraid me if you were—he deserves it from me—for he has not been more false to you, than faithless to me.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: To you!

sp.speaker: TOWNLY.
sp.p: Yes, Madam; the lady for whom he now deserts those charms which he was never worthy of, was mine by right; and I imagined too, by inclination—Yes, Madam, Berinthia, who now—

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: Berinthia!—impossible!—

sp.speaker: TOWNLY.
sp.p: 'Tis true, or may I never merit your attention.—She is the deceitful sorceress who now holds your husband's heart in bondage.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: I will not believe it.

sp.speaker: TOWNLY.
sp.p: By the faith of a true lover, I speak from conviction.—This very day I saw them together, and overheard—

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: Peace, Sir, I will not even listen to such slander—this is a poor device to work on my resentment, to listen to your insidious addresses. No, Sir; though Mr. Loveless may be capable of error, I am convinced I cannot be deceived so grossly in him, as to believe what you now report; and for Berinthia, you should have fixed on some more probable person for my rival, than she who is my relation, and my friend: for while I am myself free from guilt, I will never believe that love can beget injury, or confidence create ingratitude.

sp.speaker: TOWNLY.
sp.p: If I do not prove this to you—

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: You never shall have an opportunity—from the artful manner in which you first shew'd yourself to me, I might have been led, as far as virtue permitted, to have thought you less criminal than unhappy—but this last unmanly artifice merits at once my resentment and contempt. [Exit.

sp.speaker: TOWNLY.
sp.p:
Sure there's divinity about her; and she has dispensed some portion of honor's light to me:
yet can I bear to lose Berinthia without revenge or compensation?—Perhaps she is not so culpable as I thought her. I was mistaken when I began to think lightly of Amanda's virtue, and may be in my censure of my Berinthia.—Surely I love her still; for I feel I should be happy to find myself in the wrong. [Exit.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: Your servant, Mr. Loveless.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: Your servant, Madam.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: Pray, what do you think of this?

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: Truly, I don't know what to say.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: Don't you think we steal forth two contemptible creatures?

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: Why tolerable—so I must confess.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: And do you conceive it possible for you ever to give Amanda the least uneasiness again?

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: No, I think we never should, indeed.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: We!—why, monster, you don't pretend that I ever entertain'd a thought.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p:
Why then, sincerely, and honestly, Berinthia, there is something in my wife's conduct which strikes me so forcibly, that if it were not for shame,
and the fear of hurting you in her opinion, I swear I would follow her, confess my error, and trust to her generosity for forgiveness.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: Nay, prithee don't let your respect for me prevent you; for as my object in trifling with you was nothing more than to pique Townly; and as I perceive he has been actuated by a similar motive, you may depend on't I shall make no mystery of the matter to him.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: By no means inform him—for tho' I may chuse to pass by his conduct without resentment, how will he presume to look me in the face again!

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: How will you presume to look him in the face again?

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: He—who has dared to attempt the honour of my wife!

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: You—who have dared to attempt the honour of his mistress!—Come, come, be ruled by me who affect more levity than I have, and don't think of anger in this cause. A Readiness to resent injuries, is a virtue only in those who are slow to injure.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: Then I will be ruled by you—and when you shall think proper to undeceive Townly, may your good qualities make as sincere a convert of him, as Amanda's have of me. When truth's extended from us, then we own the robe of virtue is a secret habit.
sp.l: Could women but our secret counsels scan—
Could they but reach the deep reserve of man—
To keep our love—they'd rate their virtue high—
They live together, and together die!

div2.head: SCENE, Sir TUNBELLY'S HOUSE.
div2.stage: Enter MISS HOYDEN, NURSE, and Y. FASHION.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: This quick dispatch of the chaplain's I take so kindly, it shall give him claim to my favour as long as I live, I assure you.

sp.speaker: MISS.
sp.p: And to mine too, I promise you.

sp.speaker: NURSE.
sp.p: I most humbly thank your honors; and may your children swarm about you, like bees about a honey-comb.

sp.speaker: MISS.
sp.p: I'cod with all my heart—the more the merrier, I say—ha Nurse?

div2.stage: Enter LORY, taking Y. FASHION hastily aside.

sp.speaker: LORY.
sp.p: One word with you, for Heav'ns sake.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: What the Devil's the matter?

sp.speaker: LORY.
sp.p:
Sir, your fortune's ruin'd, if you are not married—yonder's your brother, arrived with two coaches and six horses, twenty footmen, and a coat
worth fourscore pounds—so judge what will become of your Lady's heart.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Is he in the house yet?

sp.speaker: LORY.
sp.p: No—they are capitulating with him at the gate—Sir Tunbelly luckily takes him for an impostor, and I have told him that we had heard of this plot before.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: That's right: (to Miss) my dear, here's a troublesome business my man tells me of, but don't be frighten'd, we shall be too hard for the rogue.—Here's an impudent fellow at the gate (not knowing I was come hither incognito) has taken my name upon him, in hopes to run away with you.

sp.speaker: MISS.
sp.p: O the brazen-faced varlet, it's well we are married, or may be we might never have been so.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: (Aside) Egad like enough.—Prithee, Nurse, run to Sir Tunbelly, and stop him from going to the gate before I speak with him.

sp.speaker: NURSE.
sp.p: An't please your honour, my Lady and I had best lock ourselves up till the danger be over.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Do so, if you please.

sp.speaker: MISS.
sp.p: Not so fast—I won't be lock'd up any more, now I'm married.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Yes, pray, my dear do, till we have seiz'd this rascal.

sp.speaker: MISS.
sp.p: Nay, if you'll pray me, I'll do any thing. [Exit Miss and Nurse.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: (To Lory.) Hark you, sirrah, things are better than you imagine. The wedding's over.

sp.speaker: LORY.
sp.p: (Aside.) The Devil it is, Sir!

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Not a word—all's safe—but Sir Tunbelly don't know it, nor must not, yet. So I am resolved to brazen the business out, and have the pleasure of turning the impostor upon his Lordship, which I believe may easily be done.

div2.stage: Enter SIR TUNBELLY, and SERVANTS, armed. with clubs, pitch-forks, &c.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Did you ever hear, Sir, of so impudent an undertaking?

sp.speaker: SIR TUNBELLY.
sp.p: Never, by the Mass—but we'll tickle him, I'll warrant you.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: They tell me, Sir, he has a great many people with him, disguised like servants.

sp.speaker: SIR TUNBELLY.
sp.p: Ay, ay, rogues enow—but we have master'd them.—We only fired a few shot over their heads, and the regiment scower'd in an instant.—Here, Tommas, bring in your prisoner.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p:
If you please, Sir Tunbelly, it will be best for
me not to confront the fellow yet, till you have heard how far his impudence will carry him.

sp.speaker: SIR TUNBELLY.
sp.p: 'Egad, your Lordship is an ingenious person. Your Lordship then will please to step aside.

sp.speaker: LORY.
sp.p: (Aside.) 'Fore Heaven I applaud my master's modesty. (Exe. Young Fashion and Lory.

div2.stage: Enter SERVANTS, with LORD FOPPINGTON, disarmed.

sp.speaker: SIR TUNBELLY.
sp.p: Come—bring him along, bring him along.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: What the pax do you mean, gentlemen, is it fair time that you are all drunk before supper?

sp.speaker: SIR TUNBELLY.
sp.p: Drunk, sirrah!—here's an impudent rogue for you. Drunk, or sober, bully, I'm a Justice of the Peace, and know how to deal with strollers.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Strollers!

sp.speaker: SIR TUNBELLY.
sp.p: Aye, strollers.—Come, give an account of yourself.—What's your name? Where do you live? Do you pay scot and lot? Come, are you a freeholder or a copyholder?

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: And why dost thou ask me so many impertinent questions?

sp.speaker: SIR TUNBELLY.
sp.p: Because I'll make you answer 'em before I have done with you, you rascal, you.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Before Gad, all the answers I can make to 'em, is, that you are a very extraordinary old fellow, stap my vitals!

sp.speaker: SIR TUNBELLY.
sp.p: Nay, if thou are for joking with Deputy Lieutenants, we know how to deal with you—Here, draw a warrant for him immediately.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: A warrant!—What the Devil is't thou would'st be at, old gentleman?

sp.speaker: SIR TUNBELLY.
sp.p: I would be at you, siriah, (if my hands were not tied as a Magistrate) and with these two double fists beat your teeth down your throat you dog you.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: And why would'st thou spoil my face at that rate?

sp.speaker: SIR TUNBELLY.
sp.p: For your design to rob me of my daughter, villain.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Rab thee of your daughter! Now do I begin to believe I am in bed and asleep, and that all this is but a dream. Prithee, old father, wilt thou give me leave to ask thee one question?

sp.speaker: SIR TUNBELLY.
sp.p: I can't tell whether I will or not, till I know what it is.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Why then it is, whether thou didst not write to my Lord Foppington to come down and marry thy daughter?

sp.speaker: SIR TUNBELLY.
sp.p: Yes, marry did I, and my Lord Foppington is come down, and shall marry my daughter before she's a day older.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Now give me thy hand, old dad, I thought we should understand one another at last.

sp.speaker: SIR TUNBELLY.
sp.p: This fellow's mad—here, bind him hand and foot. [They bind him.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Nay, prithee Knight, leave fooling, thy jest begins to grow dull.

sp.speaker: SIR TUNBELLY.
sp.p: Bind him, I say—he's mad—bread and water, a dark room, and a whip, may bring him to his senses again.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Prithee, Sir Tunbelly, why should you take such an aversion to the freedom of my address, as to suffer the rascals thus to skewer down my arms like a rabbit? 'Egad, if I don't waken quickly, by all that I can see, this is like to prove one of the most impertinent dreams that ever I dreamt in my life. (Aside.

sp.speaker: MISS.
sp.p: (Going up to him.) Is this he that would have run away with me? Fough! how he stinks of sweets!—Pray, father, let him be dragged thro' the horse-pond.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON,
sp.p: (Aside.) This must be my wife, by her natural inclination to her husband.

sp.speaker: MISS.
sp.p: Pray, father, what do you intend to do with him—hang him?

sp.speaker: SIR TUNBELLY.
sp.p: That, at least, child.

sp.speaker: NURSE.
sp.p: Aye, and it's e'en too good for him too.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: (Aside.) Madame la Governante, I presume; hitherto this appears to me to be one of the most extraordinary families that ever man of quality match'd into.

sp.speaker: SIR TUNBELLY.
sp.p: What's become of my Lord, daughter?

sp.speaker: MISS.
sp.p: He's just coming, Sir.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: (Aside.) My Lord!—What does he mean by that, now?

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Stap my vitals, Tam, now the dream's out.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Is this the fellow, Sir, that design'd to trick me of your daughter?

sp.speaker: SIR TUNBELLY.
sp.p: This is he, my Lord; how do you like him? is not he a pretty fellow to get a fortune?

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: I find by his dress, he thought your daughter might be taken with a beau.

sp.speaker: MISS.
sp.p:
O gemini! Is this a beau? Let me see him again.
Ha! I find a beau is no such ugly thing, neither.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: 'Egad, she'll be in love with him presently.—I'll e'en have him sent away to gaol. (To Lord Fop.) Sir, tho' your undertaking shews you a person of no extraordinary modesty, I suppose you ha'n't confidence enough to expect much favour from me.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINOTON.
sp.p: Strike me dumb, Tam, thou art a very impudent fellow.

sp.speaker: NURSE.
sp.p: Look; if the varlot has not the frontery to call his Lordship, plain Thomas.

sp.speaker: SIR TUNBELLY.
sp.p: Come, is the warrant writ?

sp.speaker: CHAPLAIN.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Hold, one moment.—Pray gentlemen—my Lord Foppington, shall I beg one word with your Lordship?

sp.speaker: NURSE.
sp.p: O, ho, it's my Lord, with him now; see how afflictions will humble folks.

sp.speaker: MISS.
sp.p: Pray, my Lord, don't let him whisper too close, lest he bite your ear off.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p:
I am not altogether so hungry as your Ladyship is pleased to imagine. (To Y. Fashion.) Look you, Tam, I am sensible I have not been so kind to you as I ought, but I hope you'll forgive what's past, and except of the five thousand pounds I
offer. Thou may'st live in extreme splendor with it, stap my vitals!

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: It's a much easier matter to prevent a disease, than to cure it. A quarter of that sum would have secured your mistress, twice as much won't redeem her. [Leaving him.

sp.speaker: SIR TUNBELLY.
sp.p: Well, what says he?

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Only the rascal offered me a bribe to let him go.

sp.speaker: SIR TUNBELLY.
sp.p: Aye, he shall go, with a halter to him—lead on, Constable.

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: Sir, here is Muster Loveless, and Muster Colonel Townly, and some ladies, to wait on you.

sp.speaker: LORY.
sp.p: (Aside.) So, Sir, What will you do now?

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Be quiet—they are in the plot. (To Sir Tunbelly.) Only a few friends, Sir Tunbelly, whom I wish'd to introduce to you.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Thou art the most impudent fellow, Tam, that ever Nature yet brought into the world. Sir Tunbelly, strike me speechless, but these are my friends and my guests, and they will soon inform thee, whether I am the true Lord Foppington or not.

div2.stage: Enter LOVELESS, TOWNLY, AMANDA, and BERINTHIA.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: So, gentlemen, this is friendly; I rejoice to see you.

sp.speaker: TOWNLY.
sp.p: My Lord, we are fortunate to be the witnesses of your Lordship's happiness.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: But your Lordship will do us the honour to introduce us to Sir Tunbelly Clumsey?

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: And us to your Lady.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Ged take me, but they are all in a story.

sp.speaker: SIR TUNBELLY.
sp.p: Gentlemen, you do me great honour; my Lord Foppington's friends will ever be welcome to me and mine.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: My love, let me introduce you to these ladies.

sp.speaker: MISS.
sp.p: By goles, they look so fine and so stiff, I am almost asham'd to come nigh 'em.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: A most engaging lady, indeed!

sp.speaker: MISS.
sp.p: Thank ye, Ma'am!

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: And I doubt not will soon distinguish herself in the Beau Monde.

sp.speaker: MISS.
sp.p: Where is that?

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: You'll soon learn, my dear.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: But, Lord Foppington—

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: Sir! I was not addressing myself to you, Sir; pray who is this gentleman? He seems rather in a singular predicament.

sp.speaker: SIR TUNBELLY.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!—So, these are your friends and your guests, ha, my adventurer?

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: I am struck dumb with their impudence, and cannot positively say whether I shall ever speak again or not.

sp.speaker: SIR TUNBELLY.
sp.p: Why, Sir, this modest gentleman wanted to pass himself upon me for Lord Foppington, and carry off my daughter.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: A likely plot to succeed, truly, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: As Gad shall judge me, Loveless, I did not expect this from thee; come, prithee confess the joke; tell Sir Tunbelly that I am the real Lord Foppington, who yesterday made love to thy wife; was honour'd by her with a slap on the face, and afterward pink'd thro' the body by thee.

sp.speaker: SIR TUNBELLY.
sp.p: A likely story, truly, that a Peer wou'd behave thus!

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: A curious fellow indeed! that wou'd scandalize the character he wants to assume; but what will you do with him, Sir Tunbelly?

sp.speaker: SIR TUNBELLY.
sp.p: Commit him certainly, unless the bride and bridegroom chuse to pardon him.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Bride and bridegroom! For Gad's sake, Sir Tunbelly, 'tis tarture to me to hear you call 'em so.

sp.speaker: MISS.
sp.p: Why, you ugly thing, what would you have him call us? dog and cat!

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: By no means, Miss; for that sounds ten times more like man and wife, than t'other.

sp.speaker: SIR TUNBELLY.
sp.p: A precious rogue this, to come a wooing!

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: There are some more gentlefolks below, to wait upon Lord Foppington.

sp.speaker: TOWNLY.
sp.p: S'death, Tom, what will you do now?

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Now, Sir Tunbelly, here are witnesses, who I believe are not corrupted.

sp.speaker: SIR TUNBELLY.
sp.p: Peace, fellow!—Wou'd your Lordship chuse to have your guests shewn here, or shall they wait till we come to 'em?

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: I believe, Sir Tunbelly, we had better not have these visitors here yet; 'egad, all must out! [Aside.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: Confess, confess, we'll stand by you.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Nay, Sir Tunbelly, I insist on your calling evidence on both sides, and if I do not prove that fellow an impostor—

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Brother, I will save you the trouble, by now confessing, that I am not what I have passed myself for;—Sir Tunbelly, I am a gentleman, and I flatter myself a man of character; but 'tis with great pride I assure, I am not Lord Foppington.

sp.speaker: SIR TUNBELLY.
sp.p: Oun's!—what's this!—an impostor!—a cheat!—fire and faggots, Sir!—if you are not Lord Foppington, who the Devil are you?

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Sir, the best of my condition is, I am your son in-law, and the worst of it is, I am brother to that noble Peer.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Impudent to the last!

sp.speaker: SIR TUNBELLY.
sp.p: My son-in-law! Not yet, I hope?

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Pardon me, Sir, thanks to the goodness of your Chaplain, and the kind offices of this old gentle woman.

sp.speaker: LORY.
sp.p: 'Tis true, indeed, Sir; I gave your daughter away, and Mrs. Nurse, here, was clerk.

sp.speaker: SIR TUNBELLY.
sp.p: Knock that rascal down!—But speak, Jezabel, how's this?

sp.speaker: NURSE.
sp.p: Alas, your honour, forgive me!—I have been overreach'd in this business as well as you; your Worship knows, if the wedding dinner had been ready, you would have given her away with your own hands.

sp.speaker: SIR TUNBELLY.
sp.p: But how durst you do this without acquainting me!

sp.speaker: NURSE.
sp.p: Alas, if your Worship had seen how the poor thing begg'd and pray'd, and clung and twin'd about me like ivy round an old wall, you wou'd say I who had nurs'd it and rear'd it, must have had a heart of stone to refuse it.

sp.speaker: SIR TUNBELLY.
sp.p: Ouns! I shall go mad! Unloose my Lord there, you scoundrels!

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Why, when these gentlemen are at leisure, I shou'd be glad to congratulate you on your son-in-law, with a little more freedom of address.

sp.speaker: MISS.
sp.p: 'Egad, tho'—I don't see which is to be my husband, after all.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: Come, come, Sir Tunbelly, a man of your understanding must perceive, that an affair of this kind is not to be mended by anger and reproaches.

sp.speaker: TOWNLY.
sp.p:
Take my word for it, Sir Tunbelly, you are
only tricked into a son-in-law you may be proud of; my friend, Tom Fashion, is as honest a fellow as ever breath'd.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: That he is, depend on't, and will hunt or drink with you most affectionately; be generous, old boy, and forgive them.

sp.speaker: SIR TUNBELLY.
sp.p: Never—the hussey:—when I had set my heart on getting her a title!

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Now, Sir Tunbelly, that I am untruss'd, give me leave to thank thee for the very extraordinary reception I have met with in thy damn'd, execrable mansion, and at the same time to assure you, that of all the bumpkins and blockheads I have had the misfortune to meet with, thou art the most obstinate and egregious, strike me ugly!

sp.speaker: SIR TUNBELLY.
sp.p: What's this!—Ouns! I believe you are both rogues alike!

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: No, Sir Tunbelly, thou wilt find to thy unspeakable mortification, that I am the real Lord Foppington, who was to have disgraced myself by an alliance with a clod; and that thou hast match'd thy girl to a beggarly younger brother of mine, whose title deeds might be contain'd in thy tobacco-box.

sp.speaker: SIR TUNBELLY.
sp.p: Puppy, puppy!—I might prevent their being beggars if I chose it;—for I cou'd give 'em as good a rent-roll as your Lordship.

sp.speaker: TOWNLY.
sp.p: Well said, Sir Tunbelly.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Aye, old fellow, but you will not do it; for that would be acting like a Christian, and thou art a thorough barbarian, stap my vitals.

sp.speaker: SIR TUNBELLY.
sp.p: Udzookers! Now six such words more, and I'll forgive them directly.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: 'Slife, Sir Tunbelly, you shou'd do it, and bless yourself; ladies what say you?

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: Good Sir Tunbelly, you must consent.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: Come, you have been young yourself, Sir Tunbelly.

sp.speaker: SIR TUNBELLY.
sp.p: Well, then, if I must, I must;—but turn that sneering Lord out, however; and let me be revenged on somebody; but first, look whether I am a barbarian, or not; there, children, I join your hands, and when I'm in a better humour, I'll give you my blessing.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: Nobly done, Sir Tunbelly; and we shall see you dance at a grandson's wedding, yet.

sp.speaker: MISS.
sp.p: By goles tho', I don't understand this; what, an't I to be a lady after all? only plain Mrs.—What's my husband's name, Nurse?

sp.speaker: NURSE.
sp.p: 'Squire Fashion.

sp.speaker: MISS.
sp.p: 'Squire, is he?—Well, that's better than nothing.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Now will I put on a Philosophic air, and shew these people, that it is not possible to put a man of my quality out of countenance. Dear, Tam, since things are thus fallen out, prythee give me leave to wish thee joy; I do it de bon coeur, strike me dumb! You have married into a family of great politeness and uncommon elegance of manners; and your bride appears to be a lady beautiful in person, modest in her deportment, refined in her sentiments, and of nice morality, split my windpipe!

sp.speaker: MISS.
sp.p: By goles, husband, break his bones, if he calls me names.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Your Lordship may keep up your spirits with your grimace, if you please, I shall support mine by Sir Tunbelly's favour, with this lady, and three thousand pounds a year.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Well, adieu, Tam; ladies, I kiss your hands; Sir Tunbelly, I shall now quit thy den, but while I retain my arms, I shall remember thou art a savage, stap my vitals! [Exit.

sp.speaker: SIR TUNBELLY.
sp.p: By the mass, 'tis well he's gone, for I shou'd ha' been provok'd by and by, to ha' dun'un a mischief;—Well, if this is a Lord, I think Hoyden has luck o' her side, in troth!

sp.speaker: TOWNLY.
sp.p: She has, indeed, Sir Tunbelly, but I hear the fiddles; his Lordship, I know, had provided 'em.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: O, a dance, and a bottle, Sir Tunbelly, by all means.

sp.speaker: SIR TUNBELLY.
sp.p: I had forgot the company below; well, what—we must be merry then, ha?—and dance and drink, ha?—Well, 'fore George, you shan't say I do things by halves; son-in-law there looks like a hearty rogue, so we'll have a night of it; and which of these gay ladies will be the old man's partner, ha?—Ecod, I don't know how I came to be in so good a humour.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: Well, Sir Tunbelly, my friend and I both will endeavour to keep you so; you have done a generous action, and are entitled to our attention; and if you shou'd be at a loss to divert your new guests, we will assist you to relate to them the plot of your daughter's marriage, and his Lordship's deserved mortification, a subject which, perhaps, may afford no bad evening's entertainment.

sp.speaker: SIR TUNBELLY.
sp.p: 'Ecod, with all my heart; tho' I am a main bungler at a long story.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: Never fear, we will assist you, if the tale is judged worth being repeated; but of this you may be assured, that while the intention is evidently to please, British auditors will ever be indulgent to the errors of the performance.
